title: Is There A Case For Skepticism Of Psychedelic Therapy?
summary:
Key ideas:
- Recent discussion on the use of psychedelics in psychiatry has been overwhelmingly positive and this post reviews a case for skepticism.
- Psychedelics have been investigated mostly in small studies by true believers which often produces unreplicable results.
- Some of the most impressive stories on psychedelic use involve psychedelic-assisted psychotherapy which is not exclusive to psychedelics and psychotherapy itself has many success stories floating around.
- Ketamine and NSI-189 are good comparisons to psychedelics as revolutionary new treatments that have failed to live up to their hype.
- Between 10% and 50% of Americans have tried psychedelics and if psychedelics did something groundbreaking, it would be known by now.
- Psychedelics stimulate the insight system artificially and may produce short-lasting effects that make people feel like their problems are solved.
- Even if psychedelics work well, the FDA could make it difficult for people to access them.

Key learnings:
- It is important to be skeptical of the hype around the use of psychedelics in psychiatry.
- The use of anecdotal evidence to support the efficacy of psychedelic use in psychiatry might not be reliable.
- The FDA has a significant role to play in the adoption of these treatments.

Key questions:
- Are psychedelics actually revolutionary or have they been overhyped?
- How long-lasting are the effects of psychedelics and how do they compare to other treatments?
- What role should the FDA play in regulating the use of these treatments?
